review.title: ALARMS: Alerting and Reasoning Management System for Next Generation Aircraft Hazards
review.abstract: The Next Generation Air Transportation System will introduce new, advanced sensor technologies into the cockpit. With the introduction of such systems, the responsibilities of the pilot are expected to dramatically increase. In the ALARMS (ALerting And Reasoning Management System) project for NASA, we focus on a key challenge of this environment, the quick and efficient handling of aircraft sensor alerts. It is infeasible to alert the pilot on the state of all subsystems at all times. Furthermore, there is uncertainty as to the true hazard state despite the evidence of the alerts, and there is uncertainty as to the effect and duration of actions taken to address these alerts. This paper reports on the first steps in the construction of an application designed to handle Next Generation alerts. In ALARMS, we have identified 60 different aircraft subsystems and 20 different underlying hazards. In this paper, we show how a Bayesian network can be used to derive the state of the underlying hazards, based on the sensor input. Then, we propose a framework whereby an automated system can plan to address these hazards in cooperation with the pilot, using a Time-Dependent Markov Process (TMDP). Different hazards and pilot states will call for different alerting automation plans. We demonstrate this emerging application of Bayesian networks and TMDPs to cockpit automation, for a use case where a small number of hazards are present, and analyze the resulting alerting automation policies.

metadata.title: ALARMS: Alerting and Reasoning Management System for Next Generation Aircraft Hazards

sections.text: This paper describes the first steps in building an application designed to handle next-generation alarms. In ALARMS, we have identified 60 different aircraft subsystems and 20 different underlying hazards. In this paper, we show how a Bajesian network can be used to derive the state of the underlying hazards based on sensor input. We then propose a framework within which an automated system can plan these hazards in collaboration with the pilot using a Time-Based Markov Process (TMDP). Different hazards and pilot states will require different alarm automation plans. We demonstrate this emerging application of Bajesian networks and TMDPs to cockpit automation, for a use case where a small number of hazards exist, and analyze the resulting alarm automation plans.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: With the introduction of such systems, pilot responsibilities and the density of air traffic are expected to increase dramatically (Joint Planning and Development Office, 2007).As a result, the number of potential hazards and relevant information that the pilot needs to perceive and process will increase.This information is likely to come from a variety of sources, requiring the pilot to integrate this information in order to assess the potential hazard.The assessment of the hazardous potential will depend on taking into account and differentiating between immediate (current) hazards and situations that require (future) re-planning or co-ordination; it will also require reasoning under uncertainty, as the actual state of the world must be based on the hazards, and a plan must be drawn up to address the hazards to the pilot and artificial aviation intelligence.

sections.heading: 2 ALARMS Approach

sections.heading: 2.1 ALARMS Hazard Matrix
sections.text: As a first step in ALARMS efforts, we combined with the Aircraft Simulation and Hardware-in-the-Loop Laboratory to (1) identify current and next generation aircraft systems. (2) Aircraft Hazards. (3) The interaction between systems and hazards. The ALARMS hazard matrix was designed as a result of this work, and a small portion of this matrix is in Figure 3. Each line represents a tool, technology, or system that can trigger an alarm in the next generation cockpit. Each column represents a potential environment at risk. Therefore, there is an entry for each case in which a sensor can trigger a warning for a given hazard. Entries are also color-coded with the designations D / W / C / A (Directive / Warning / Advisory). These labels, displayed in the sequence of decreasing hazard levels, represent the highest possible alert level for the sensor / hazard combination.

sections.heading: 2.2 ALARMS Bayesian Network
sections.text: The aim of ALARMS efforts is to create a plan for dealing with sensor alarms; however, it is not really the sensor alarms that need to be processed, it is the underlying hazards that they represent. For example, several subsystems (such as Vertical Navigation (VNAV) and the Cockpit Display of Traffic Information (CDTI) may issue alerts referring to altitude deviation hazards. ALARMS should conclude that there may be altitude deviation hazards when one of these sensors issues a warning, and the hazard should be safer and more urgent when both systems trigger one. In order to model the sensor systems, a Bayesian network has been established, as shown in Figure 4. Ovals on the right represent hazards corresponding to the columns of the ALARMS hazard matrix. Ovals on the left represent hazard alerts or alarms on the left.

sections.heading: 3 Application

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: In the ALARMS project, we have developed several components necessary to operate aircraft in a NextGen environment. First, a study of existing systems was conducted and a matrix was created that correlates the sensor performance of aircraft (both legacy and NextGen) with the hazards of the real world. Second, this matrix was used to create a Bayesian network where sensor output becomes evidence and the presence and severity of real hazards is derived. Third, a TMDP model was created that allows the aircraft sensor system to select the appropriate level of automation that best addresses the hazards in a time-dependent environment. Finally, a demonstration application was created that links the applications and thus creates automation plans directly from the simulated sensor output.
